head.title: A Month That Couldn't End Fast Enough

identified-content.classifier: Top/Classifieds/Job Market/Job Categories/Banking, Finance and Insurance

hedline.hl1: A Month That Couldn't End Fast Enough

abstract.p: Dow Jones industrial average falls 5 percent for September, Nasdaq composite index falls 12.7 percent and Standard & Poor's 500-stock index drops 5.4 percent; graphs; charts (M)

block.p: Investors hope that it's over now -- the punishing string of earnings warnings that has relentlessly pushed down stocks, especially the high-wire technology stocks. Apple, Intel, Sprint, Eastman Kodak, UAL and a host of other big names announced that they would disappoint Wall Street as the third quarter closed.

Will the fourth quarter be any kinder? Many analysts look for a rebound by year's end, but others fear that the economy may not have such a soft landing after all, that computer sales growth will falter and that Wall Street's wall of worry may be harder to climb.

Investors hope that it's over now -- the punishing string of earnings warnings that has relentlessly pushed down stocks, especially the high-wire technology stocks. Apple, Intel, Sprint, Eastman Kodak, UAL and a host of other big names announced that they would disappoint Wall Street as the third quarter closed.

Will the fourth quarter be any kinder? Many analysts look for a rebound by year's end, but others fear that the economy may not have such a soft landing after all, that computer sales growth will falter and that Wall Street's wall of worry may be harder to climb.

''It's just a continuation of what we've seen since Labor Day,'' said John Shaughnessy, chief investment strategist at Advest. ''This is a combination of the concerns about third-quarter earnings reports, the implications of rising oil prices for the economy and corporate profit, and the implications of the weak euro.''
The Dow Jones industrials fell 5 percent for the month, the Nasdaq composite lost 12.7 percent and the S. & P. 500 slipped 5.4 percent in September.

There was relief that September had ended and hope for an upswing in October. But the pessimists pointed out that it can be a harsh month for stocks: Big market drops have a way of happening in October.
